As a petroleum engineer, I have to be careful forecasting questions where I have enhanced and lengthy experience. As such I develop a bias that is harder to shake with new data that should sway me. Citgo is a refiner. The refining business is very, very stable. Fuel consumption is very predictable, storage is stable, transport costs are predictable. The business side of this question has no indicators of large uncertainty or surprise costs. There have been floods that may or may not have affected the business, but that isn't why this question was proposed, It is because of the Venezuelan sanctions, as Citgo is wholly owned by the government of Venezuela. In March, 2019 the US Treasury took the unusual steps to refinance Citgo to keep those American jobs. Cited- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citgo Further, I've found good intel on health of companies based on their hiring practices, in this case, hiring is normal - http://www.citgo.com/careers/opportunities/current-opportunities There is absolutely no google news since Q1 about a possible bankruptcy. A leak about it would be highly likely, so I up my prediction there is no bankruptcy coming.
Time.

PDV 2020 bond is secured by 50.1pc of the shares of Citgo´s indirect parent company PdV Holding(PDVH). PdV has made $71mn interest payment in April 2019 and will owe $842mn in principal in October 2019 on the 2020 bond. Very unlikely(1%<) that Citgo will file for bakruptcy protection before 1 August 2019 because of that obligation.

Venezuelan crude oil production falls to lowest level since January 2003 In March 2019, Venezuela's crude oil production (excluding condensate) averaged 840,000 barrels per day (b/d), down from 1.1 million b/d in February, according to estimates in the U.S. Energy Information Administration's (EIA) April 2019 Short-Term Energy Outlook. This average is the lowest level since January 2003, when a nationwide strike and civil unrest largely brought Venezuela's state oil company, Petróleos de Venezuela, S.A.'s (PdVSA), operations to a halt. Widespread power outages, mismanagement of the country's oil industry, and U.S. sanctions directed at Venezuela's energy sector and PdVSA have all contributed to the recent declines. Venezuela's production decreased by an average of 33,000 b/d each month in 2018, and the rate of decline accelerated to an average of over 135,000 b/d per month in the first quarter of 2019. The number of active oil rigs—an indicator of future oil production—also fell from nearly 70 rigs in the first quarter of 2016 to 24 rigs in the first quarter of 2019. The declines in Venezuelan production will have limited effects on the United States, as U.S. imports of Venezuelan crude oil have decreased over the last several years, with average 2018 imports the lowest since 1989. However, there may be upward pressure on the prices of other crude oils imported into the United States.

As it stands, Venezuela's oil output has been significantly constrained by global sanctions. Citgo's US assets are its most valuable as a result of the inactivity in Venezuela, and since the country is clambering for value (like using some of its gold reserves to cover foreign debt), I believe it is likely to try to seize the US assets for sale. Therefore, I think Citgo US (and possibly other foreign subsidiaries) will file for bankruptcy protection to prevent seizure by the Venezuelan government.

CITGO is an insulated entity. The opco and holdco stand alone credit profile plus the potential for government support is higher than the group credit profile. The subsidiary's financial performance and funding prospects are highly independent from those of the group, so that even if other core entities encounter severe setbacks, the relative strength of the subsidiary will remain nearly intact. The subsidiary is severable from the group and able to stand on its own or subcontract certain functions previously provided by the parent. The parent's strategy with respect to the subsidiary is clear and, in particular, the parent has a compelling economic incentive to preserve the subsidiary's credit strength; and it is unlikely that the subsidiary will be drawn into bankruptcy proceedings at the group level that would lead to a default on the subsidiary's obligations.

So, on the one hand, Citgo seems back on track, with the Aruba unit soon to be working again (which means oil will flow from Venezuela to Citgo, at least during the 18 month agreement, and that same terminal was where ConocoPhillips was going to seize cargos to get repaid...) https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-refinery-aruba/aruba-to-resume-refinery-refurbishment-after-u-s-sanctions-exemption-idUSKCN1QY0NY and the company is borrowing some operating money https://www.reuters.com/article/us-citgo-debt/us-refiner-citgo-taking-offers-on-18-billion-three-year-loan-sources-idUSKCN1R22IH https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-20/citgo-is-said-to-boost-loan-to-1-8-billion-amid-strong-demand

This is a question of time. Maduro has no interest on paying the debt and interests (PDVSA's 2020 bond) as he has no access to proceeds or funds to keep him in power. This is the same reason Guaidó wants to "protect and control the Venezuelan assets" (plus, maybe, he is thinking about the future). CITGO has been challenged in the past as alter ego of PDVSA in other litigations. There could also be a motivation for Maduro to default, the $1.5B loan from Rosneft, backed with 49.9% of CITGO as collateral to give half of the company to his friend and supporter Putin. US administration will not let this happen and I assume Guaidó will try to avoid this at any cost as well.

Citgo is worthless given Trump's and Bolton's bluster. Even Marco Rubio has joined in. And given that no oil money earned can be transferred back Citgo is now worthless and an expense not worth servicing the debt. It would also mean the opposition can get no use of an asset in litigation before courts for the next decade. Win win with no downsides.

Sooner or later someone in the Orange House will bring to the attention of the Current Incumbent that PDVSA owns Citgo. A midnight Twitstorm will ensue, and my personal guess is that all of PDVSA's assets in the US will be frozen (even the ones in Lake Charles, where nothing ever freezes). In there somewhere, Citgo will go for bankruptcy protection, but I am inclined to suspect that none of this will happen as soon as this Q contemplates.
